facts.text: Agreement dated January 2, 1931 appointed Lala Manmohan Das as treasurer of Allahabad Bank Ltd for certain branches, sub-agencies and pay offices

anchor.surface_text: Shah, J. Under an agreement dated January 2, 1931, Lala Manmohan Das - hereinafter called the assessee was appointed treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Ltd. in respect of certain branches, sub-agencies and pay offices.

facts.text: Assessee assessed to income-tax as representing his Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was assessed to income-tax as representing his Hindu undivided family, and the income received by the assessee under the terms of the agreement with the Allahabad Bank was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: Income received by assessee under agreement treated as income of Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: and the income received by the assessee under the terms of the agreement with the Allahabad Bank was treated as income of the Hindu undivided family. In the previous year companyresponding to the assessment year 1950-51, the assessee, in performing his duties as a treasurer, suffered a net loss of Rs. 38,027.

facts.text: In previous year corresponding to assessment year 1950-51, assessee suffered net loss of Rs. 38,027 as treasurer

anchor.surface_text: In the previous year companyresponding to the assessment year 1950-51, the assessee, in performing his duties as a treasurer, suffered a net loss of Rs. 38,027. For the assessment year 1951-52, the profit and loss account of the assessee showed Rs. 73,815 as receipts, against which were debited outgoings amounting to Rs. 39,370 which included Rs. 20,000 being the loss suffered by the assessee as treasurer of the Patna branch of the Allahabad Bank arising from misappropriation by an assistant cashier.

facts.text: For assessment year 1951-52, profit and loss account showed receipts Rs. 73,815, outgoings Rs. 39,370 including Rs. 20,000 loss from Patna branch due to misappropriation by assistant cashier

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1951-52, the profit and loss account of the assessee showed Rs. 73,815 as receipts, against which were debited outgoings amounting to Rs. 39,370 which included Rs. 20,000 being the loss suffered by the assessee as treasurer of the Patna branch of the Allahabad Bank arising from misappropriation by an assistant cashier. The Income-tax Officer refused to allow the losssuffered in the previous year to be set off against the net profit of Rs. 34,445 and brought that amount of profit to tax as remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank.

facts.text: Net profit for 1951-52 was Rs. 34,445

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer refused to allow the losssuffered in the previous year to be set off against the net profit of Rs. 34,445 and brought that amount of profit to tax as remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank. The order of the Income- tax Officer was companyflrmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer refused to allow loss from previous year to be set off against net profit of Rs. 34,445 and taxed it as remuneration

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer refused to allow the losssuffered in the previous year to be set off against the net profit of Rs. 34,445 and brought that amount of profit to tax as remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank. The order of the Income- tax Officer was companyflrmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held that the remuneration received by the assessee as Treasurer of the Allahabad Bank was income arising from pursuit of a profession or vocation within the meaning of s. 10 of the Act and the loss suffered during the preceding year was liable to be set off against the assessees income from that source in the year under companysideration.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order in appeal

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income- tax Officer was companyflrmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held remuneration was income from profession or vocation under s.10 and loss set-off allowed

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., the following questions were referred to the High Court of Allahabad under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 Whether on a true interpretation of the deed of agreement dated 2nd January, 1931, appointing the assessee as treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Limited, income earned by the assessee from his activities as such treasurer fell to be companyputed under section 10 of the Act or section 7 or section 12 of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: High Court held remuneration taxed under s.10 and assessee could set off loss from 1950-51 against 1951-52 profits

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the remuneration received by the assessee from the Allahabad Bank was income liable to be taxed under section 10 of the Income-tax Act, and that the assessee companyld claim to set off the loss companyputed in the assessment year 1950-51 against the profits in the subsequent year. With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred by the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Agreement remuneration is monthly allowance total Rs. 2,250 plus Rs. 350 travelling expenses

anchor.surface_text: The remuneration of the treasurer shall be a monthly allowance for each of the branches, sub-agencies and pay offices the total of such monthly allowance to be Rs. 2,250  Rupees two thousand two hundred and fifty  plus Rs. 350  Rupees three hundred and fifty  for travelling expenses.

facts.text: Treasurer to appoint Indian staff for cash department at salaries paid by bank, with bank approval

anchor.surface_text: The treasurer shall with the approval of the bank appoint at adequate salaries to be paid by the bank all the Indian staff as may be companysidered sufficient by the bank for the business of the cash department of the banks branches, sub-agencies and pay offices and shall dismiss any person or persons so appointed whom he shall be reasonably directed by the bank to dismiss and shall with like approval appoint another or others in the place of person or persons so dismissed.

facts.text: Treasurer responsible for acts of staff including embezzlement, theft, fraud, misappropriation, mistake, omission, negligent act or default

anchor.surface_text: The treasurer shall be responsible to the bank for the work and companyduct of every person to be appointed or employed on his staff and shall make good to the bank any loss or damage sustained or incurred by the bank from any embezzlement, theft, fraud, misappropriation, mis-conduct, mistake, omission, negligent act or default of any such person or persons.

facts.text: Agreement terminable by either party giving three calendar months written notice

anchor.surface_text: The treasurers employment may be determined at any time by either party giving to the other three calendar months written numberice to that effect, and in the case of the treasurers death, this agreement as regards the treasurers liabilities and obligations for the staff and other persons shall remain in force so as to bind his heirs, representatives and estate for any future claim of the bank in respect of any subsequent transaction or occurrence unless and until determined by his heirs or representatives giving like numberice to the bank.

facts.text: Supreme Court held treasurer not a servant of the bank, remuneration not salary under s.7

anchor.surface_text: On a careful companysideration of the companyenants, we are of the view that the treasurer was number a servant of the Allahabad Bank under the terms of the agreement dated January 2, 1931, and the remuneration received by him was number salaries within the meaning of section 7 of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held occupation of treasurer is a vocation, remuneration computed under s.10, loss set-off allowed under s.24(2)

anchor.surface_text: Taking into companysideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to companypensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation. The remuneration must therefore be companyputed under s. IO of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.

Whether on a true interpretation of the deed of agreement dated 2nd January, 1931, appointing the assessee as treasurer of the Allahabad Bank Limited, income earned by the assessee from his activities as such treasurer fell to be computed under section 10 of the Act or section 7 or section 12 of the Income-tax Act ? anchor.surface_text: This Court in Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra observed The principles according to which the relationship as between employer and employee or master and servant has got to be determined are well settled. The test which is uniformly applied in order to determine the relationship is the existence of a right of control in respect of the manner in which the work is to be done. A distinction is also drawn between a contract for service and a contract of service and that distinction is put in this way In the one case the master can order or require what is to be done while in the other case he can not only order or require what is to be done but how itself it shall be done.

concepts.interpretation: Existence of right of control determines master-servant relationship; applied to hold no such control over treasurer

holdings.reasoning_summary: The statutory right to carry forward and set off loss under s.24(2) is to be determined by the ITO assessing the subsequent year; s.24(3) only requires notification of computed loss and does not bind the assessee or subsequent assessment.

holdings.text: Receipt of remuneration for holding an office does not necessarily give rise to a relationship of master and servant between the holder of the office and the person who pays the remuneration.

precedents.citation: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri on behalf of the revenue contended, relying upon Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd., and Piyare Lal Adishwar Lal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, that under the contracts substantially similar to the contract in this case, treasurers were held merely to be servants of the banks, business whereof they attended.

anchor.surface_text: Taking into consideration the nature of the duties performed, and the obligations undertaken, together with the right to remuneration subject to compensation for loss arising to the Bank from his own acts and omissions or of the servants introduced by him into the business of the Bank, the assessee may be regarded as following a vocation. The remuneration must therefore be computed under s. IO of the Income-tax Act and loss of profit suffered in that vocation in any year may be carried forward to the next year and be set off against the profit of the succeeding year.
